) This IRM provides specific procedural guidance for international revenue officers when requesting adjustments on certain documents involving tional taxpayers. These procedures may also have applications that revenue officers will find useful. (
) The audience for this IRM is revenue officers in SB/SE Field Collection (

) Ensuring compliance with U.S. tax law in international cases can be complex. As an international revenue officer (RO), you must consider a / SFR er’s tax status, sources of foreign income, and applicable treaties when determining the taxpayer’s filing requirements. (
) For Automated Substitute for Return or Substitute for Return (ASFR/SFR) considerations on U.S. citizens and resident aliens living abroad, an original Form
, U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, must be submitted with priate forms and schedules (i.e. Form
, Foreign Earned Income, Form
, Foreign Tax Credit). Any Form

, Request for Adjustment, for a citizen, resident alien, or green card holder must have an original return submitted. The return must bear an official IRS date stamp and an original signature. If a joint return, both parties must sign the tax return (
) An international revenue officer must generally secure an original Form

NR, U.S. Non-resident Alien Income Tax Return, with all supporting schedules to submit for an adjustment on ASFR/SFR cases for aliens. Note: There may be instances where securing an original return from an tional taxpayer is not possible or practical. An adjustment request can be submitted without an original return if warranted by the circumstances, only with managerial approval on Form
Before approving, the manager will review to assure that the revenue officer received answers pertinent questions regarding citizenship, substantial presence test, and fectively connected income. (

) This IRM provides specific procedural guidance for international revenue officers when requesting adjustments on certain documents involving interna- tional taxpayers. These procedures may also have applications that domestic revenue officers will find useful. (
) The audience for this IRM is revenue officers in SB/SE Field Collection (FC). (

) Ensuring compliance with U.S. tax law in international cases can be complex. As an international revenue officer (RO), you must consider a ASFR / SFR er’s tax status, sources of foreign income, and applicable treaties when determining the taxpayer’s filing requirements. (
) For Automated Substitute for Return or Substitute for Return (ASFR/SFR) re- considerations on U.S. citizens and resident aliens living abroad, an original Form
, U.S. Individual Income Tax Return, must be submitted with priate forms and schedules (i.e. Form
, Foreign Earned Income, Form
, Foreign Tax Credit). Any Form

, Request for Adjustment, for a citizen, resident alien, or green card holder must have an original return submitted. The return must bear an official IRS date stamp and an original signature. If a joint return, both parties must sign the tax return (
) An international revenue officer must generally secure an original Form

NR, U.S. Non-resident Alien Income Tax Return, with all supporting schedules to submit for an adjustment on ASFR/SFR cases for non-resident aliens. Note: There may be instances where securing an original return from an interna- tional taxpayer is not possible or practical. An adjustment request can be submitted without an original return if warranted by the circumstances, but only with managerial approval on Form

International and Insular (

) For non-resident aliens (NRAs) with an ASFR/SFR adjustment, when no is secured further investigation is required to determine the taxability of the income. In addition to analyzing sources of income and provisions of appli- cable treaties, you will have to verify a taxpayer’s personal documentation research internal and external locator sources when appropriate. Do not request adjustment without actually communicating with the taxpayer and obtaining any needed information or applicable return. (

) The key to recommending an adjustment on an NRA assessment is that are not just taking the taxpayer’s word for not being liable to file. It may not always be possible to determine or verify the taxpayer’s status when ing an international adjustment. It will be necessary to rely on a of evidence that reasonably seems to confirm what the taxpayer indicates you by both the taxpayer’s proof and/or the use of locator sources. (

) The following are guidelines that must be considered in adjusting assessments regarding NRAs. for Note: Contact with the taxpayer or power of attorney is mandatory for any Adjustments adjustment. If the taxpayer claims identify theft issues are present, IRM
, Identify Theft, for proper actions. (
) Determine taxpayer’s citizenship: (cid:
) To determine citizenship IDRS CC MFTRAU or CC DDBKD, passport or green card may be considered. (cid:

) A copy of a foreign passport provided by the taxpayer to justify an abatement is not sufficient, but can be submitted as part of supporting evidence if it is complete and current with all pages present. (
) Determine if there is effectively connected income: (cid:
) Effectively connected income is determined by taxpayer involvement in U.S. trade or business. See IRC
(b) and (c). (cid:

) Activities that constitute being engaged in a U.S. trade or business personal services, self-employment, partnership income, income as a eficiary of an estate or trust, or certain activities relating to trading in securities. (
) Determine if taxpayer meets the substantial presence test: (cid:
) Subject to certain limited exceptions, an individual meets this test if he been present in the U.S. for at least
days during a three-year period that includes at least
days in the current year. See IRC
). (cid:

) Confirmation must be made when taxpayers claim that they have not in the U.S., and therefore are not liable for U.S. tax. You must document the application of the substantial presence test in all adjustment dations. (cid:

) There are investigative tools that you can use to determine a person’s in the U.S., such as Treasury Enforcement Communication System historical travel data and Department of State records of registration with U.S. Consulate in a foreign country. Although these tools do not provide absolutely complete record of a taxpayer’s time in the U.S., it may help indicate when a taxpayer was present in the country. It does provide arrival and departure information on NRAs.
5.21 International and Insular
For non

resident aliens (NRAs) with an ASFR/SFR adjustment, when no is secured further investigation is required to determine the taxability of the income. In addition to analyzing sources of income and provisions of appli

cable treaties, you will have to verify a taxpayer’s personal documentation or research internal and external locator sources when appropriate. Do not request adjustment without actually communicating with the taxpayer and obtaining any needed information or applicable return.

The key to recommending an adjustment on an NRA assessment is that you are not just taking the taxpayer’s word for not being liable to file. It may not always be possible to determine or verify the taxpayer’s status when consider- ing an international adjustment. It will be necessary to rely on a of evidence that reasonably seems to confirm what the taxpayer indicates to you by both the taxpayer’s proof and/or the use of locator sources.
(cid:
) Subject to certain limited exceptions, an individual meets this test if he has been present in the U.S. for at least
days during a three-year period that includes at least
days in the current year. See IRC
). (cid:

) Confirmation must be made when taxpayers claim that they have not been in the U.S., and therefore are not liable for U.S. tax. You must document the application of the substantial presence test in all adjustment recommen- dations. (cid:

) There are investigative tools that you can use to determine a person’s time in the U.S., such as Treasury Enforcement Communication System (TECS) historical travel data and Department of State records of registration with a U.S. Consulate in a foreign country. Although these tools do not provide an absolutely complete record of a taxpayer’s time in the U.S., it may help to indicate when a taxpayer was present in the country. It does provide both arrival and departure information on NRAs.
to International Cases 5.21.8
) Determine if taxpayer paid the taxes to a foreign government, and (cid:

) Taxpayer may indicate that they paid taxes to the foreign government and do not owe the U.S. taxes. Taxpayer must provide evidence of payment the form of a cancelled check, documentation of a wire transfer, a copy of the relevant return filed in the foreign country, or other indication of taxes withheld by a foreign government, pursuant to a treaty. (
) Determine if there is an applicable treaty. (cid:
) Taxpayer may claim that the income is not taxable based on an income treaty with the foreign country. The taxpayer may provide a copy of Form
, Exemption from Withholding on Compensation for Independent (& Certain Dependent) Personal Service of a Non-resident Alien Individual, Form W-

BEN, Certificate of Foreign Status of Beneficial Owner for States Tax Withholding (Individuals), which would show that the taxpayer claimed to be an NRA with respect to U.S. compensation or U.S. source investment income. Note: NRAs are generally not required to file Form
, Treaty-Based Return Position Disclosure Under Section
or
(b), to disclose a treaty that relates to withholding on U.S. source investment income or compensa- tion from dependent personal services. See Treas. Reg.
(c). burden is on the taxpayer, however, to prove that he is a resident, and not merely a national or citizen of a country with which the United States has a treaty.
(cid:
) Taxpayer may claim that the income is not taxable based on an income tax treaty with the foreign country. The taxpayer may provide a copy of Form
, Exemption from Withholding on Compensation for Independent (& Certain Dependent) Personal Service of a Non-resident Alien Individual, or Form W-

BEN, Certificate of Foreign Status of Beneficial Owner for United States Tax Withholding (Individuals), which would show that the taxpayer claimed to be an NRA with respect to U.S. compensation or U.S. source investment income.
NRAs are generally not required to file Form
, Treaty-Based Return Position Disclosure Under Section
or
(b), to disclose a treaty claim that relates to withholding on U.S. source investment income or compensa- tion from dependent personal services. See Treas. Reg.
(c). The burden is on the taxpayer, however, to prove that he is a resident, and not merely a national or citizen of a country with which the United States has a treaty.

NRAs are generally not required to file Form 8833, Treaty-Based Return Position Disclosure Under Section 6114 or 7701(b), to disclose a treaty that relates to withholding on U.S. source investment income or compensa- tion from dependent personal services. See Treas. Reg. 301.6114-1(c). The burden is on the taxpayer, however, to prove that he is a resident, and not merely a national or citizen of a country with which the United States has a

Reminder: In the absence of a filed Form 1040NR, recommending adjustment of an NRA assessment requires verification, rather than solely relying on the taxpayer’s claim of not being subject to U.S. taxation.
(1) An Individual Taxpayer Identification Number (ITIN) is a tax processing number issued by IRS. The ITIN is only available to individuals who:
issued by IRS. The ITIN is only available to individuals who: (cid:
) Are required to have a taxpayer identification number for tax purposes, (cid:
) Do not have, and are not eligible to obtain, an SSN from the Social Security Administration (SSA), and (cid:
) Have a valid filing requirement or are filing a U.S. Federal income tax return to claim a refund of over-withheld tax. Generally a U.S. Federal income tax return must accompany the ITIN

Applications for individuals who are requesting an ITIN as a spouse or a dependent of a primary taxpayer must attach a valid U.S. Federal income tax return to the Form W-7, Application for IRS Individual Taxpayer Identi- fication Number.
Procedures for requesting an ITIN for cases in which ASFR/SFR tion is needed have often caused delays and confusion in processing Form

when submitted for processing. However, the original tax return must also be attached to Form
in order to process the request. Form
for the reconsideration request is sent to the ASFR/SFR unit. The following procedures should be used in all cases where a taxpayer is questing an ASFR/SFR reconsideration and is submitting Form W-
for an ITIN: (cid:

with the received date. (cid:

application and the original supporting determine if the form and supporting documents meet foreign status identity requirements. (Refer to the instructions for Form W-
). If the taxpayer provides copies of the supporting documents, the documents be a certified copy by the issuing agency.

Date stamp Form W-
with the received date. Review the Form W-
application and the original supporting documents to determine if the form and supporting documents meet foreign status and identity requirements. (Refer to the instructions for Form W-
). If the taxpayer provides copies of the supporting documents, the documents must be a certified copy by the issuing agency.
Note: The ITIN unit has final approval regarding the validity of the documents provided.

application, and send the original return with the Form
to the ASFR/SFR unit in Brookhaven Campus for processing. An ITIN will be assigned to the taxpayer within

) The status of the adjustment(s) can be checked using IDRS. Sometimes when filing Form
, Annual Withholding Tax Return for U.S. Source Income of Foreign Persons, a qualified intermediary (QI) mistakenly does not claim credit on line
of the form for the withholding that was done, either by himself or someone else. QIs can claim the withholding credits, based on the Forms
-S issued to them, even though they are not the actual withholding agent. In such cases, it will be necessary for the revenue officer to obtain copies of the Forms
-S, Foreign Person’s U.S. Source Income Subject to ing, issued to the QI that reflect the withholding. See IRM
, Procedures for Working Qualified Intermediary Cases.

) Before submitting an adjustment, review the forms for common errors, such entering the credit on the wrong line. (
) Forward Form

with substantiation attached to Centralized Case ing (CCP) for processing using your area mailbox. Any forms sent directly to Accounts Management (AM), without being routed through CCP, will be rejected. Caution: The name and TIN of the recipient on Form
-S must match the name and TIN on the return in which the credit is being claimed or the credit will be disallowed. See IRM
), BMF International Ad- justments. (
) The Entellitrak (E-TRAK) system can be used to secure information about the Forms

-S. When ROs request the E-TRAK information, they must put something in the Integrated Collection System (ICS) history indicating that sent the request to the group’s E-TRAK resource person, and include that person’s name. No GM approval is required and there is no need for the E-TRAK resource person to access the case to verify completion of the request. (
) For purposes of adjustment requests, at the time of this revision Accounts Management (AM) will not accept E-TRAK prints in lieu of copies of Forms
-S. However, AM has agreed to accept the information from IDRS command code IRPTRL in lieu of copies of Forms
-S. Revenue officers can use the summary page on IRPTRL as verification for Form
line
credit. The RO does not have to print all the Form
credits on IRPTR. RO must use document code
when obtaining IRPTRL prints. This will spe- cifically show the Form
credits. Note: E-TRAK sometimes has more complete information than IRPTRL so you may want to check the information from both sources. (
) The credits reflected on IRPTRL must match the credits claimed on the Form
